newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysian youth may have to do national service.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian youth may have to do national service.

text.p: A proposed non-military national service programme may be made mandatory for all Malaysian secondary school graduates as well as those pursuing tertiary courses, a local newspaper reported on Monday.
A national service programme was proposed last week as one way to combat social problems among the country's Moslem population.
"With so much concentration on the academic aspect, the moral and civic aspects were neglected during their school years," the Star newspaper quoted Deputy Education Minister Fong Chan Onn as saying.
"At the moment, we are looking at conducting the programme in the students' respective schools, but we have not finalised it," he said.
Malaysia does not have military conscription. so the proposed scheme would be the first compulsory national service for young people.

Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad last Wednesday led Moslem religious leaders, some Moslem cabinet ministers and state chief ministers in launching a campaign against drug abuse, incest and crime besetting the Moslem community in Malaysia, which makes up more than half of the country's 21 million population.

Fong said that a working paper on national service is being prepared by the Youth and Sports Ministry. The non-military service could be modelled along the lines of summer camps in the United States, Fong was quoted as saying.
The programme would focus on good moral and civic values and include a "character-building plan" for youths leaving school, he said.
"The main thing is to have a programme to strengthen the moral fibre and promote self-reliance and perseverance among the youth," he was quoted as saying.
